Message.Title: The Recovery Is Here
Message.Msg: Ever since the financial system was on the brink of complete collapse four years ago, it's been a tough slog. But that shouldn't be unexpected. This was no ordinary recession. When someone recovers from the flu, it takes a week or two before they're feeling 100%. On the other hand, if someone was in intensive care with double pneumonia, it's going to be quite a while before they're feeling back to themselves. Well, in 2008 and early 2009, not only was the U.S. economy in intensive care with double pneumonia, but Presidents Bush and Obama, along with Hank Paulson, had to break out the defibrillator a few times to revive the patient. The recuperation process was going to be long. But now the patient is home, up and moving around again and on the road to recovery. There's still a long way to go, but make no mistake about it - things are improving: In August, building permits were up 6.8% from last year. Employers added 163,000 jobs in July, higher than the 73,000 average from April - June. Timber company Weyerhauser (NYSE: WY), whose revenue is 84% tied to housing, saw second quarter revenue higher than it has been in several years. More employees are going on strike. According to Barron's, RBC Global Asset Management noted that there have been 17 incidences of walkouts with 1,000 or more employees - the highest since 2004-2005. That's a sign of confidence on the part of labor. If the 20% gains of the market over the past year were for a full calendar year, it would be the 22nd best performance in the past 84 years. The good news is 20% gains in the market has been a good indication of future economic growth. Let's take a look at the five markets closest to the past year's performance. In 1967, the stock market rose 20.02%. The following year, GDP rose by 4.8%. In 2009 and 1963, the market climbed 19.67% each year. GDP grew 3.2% in 2010 and 5.2% in 1964. In 1999, the market grew by 19.64% resulting in a 2.9% increase in GDP. And in 1996, when the market rose by 19.33%, GDP was higher by 4.4% just 12 months later. After so many years of suffering, it may be difficult to picture brighter days ahead, but rest assured, they're coming. That's not me being my usual cheerful self. That's the numbers and executives of some of America's top companies talking. After a near death experience, the patient is about to go back to work. Before you know it, he'll be back at the gym and on the golf course. Let's stop treating him as an invalid and start recognizing that things will return to normal. Disclosure: Investment U expressly forbids its writers from having a financial interest in any security they recommend to our subscribers. All employees and agents of Investment U (and affiliated companies) must wait 24 hours after an initial trade recommendation is published on online - or 72 hours after a direct mail publication is sent - before acting on that recommendation.

Message.Title: Another Day
Message.Msg: Another day of Wall Street telling us the sky is falling and beating the Intel stock price down. Wall Street has bet big on economic collapse. Except it's not happening. Have you had enough yet? Don't get mad, get even. Write the letters. Fudzilla Headline: TSMC tells Apple and Qualcomm where to stick their money So, now Apple is stuck with Samsung. LOL. Now that's funny. ARMs fabrication is falling apart, can't meet demand, can't produce enough 28nm products, can't satisfy customers, can't stay on the cutting edge of technology and yet Wall Street gives ARM the big P/E ratio while apparently in lockstep continuing to manipulate the Intel stock price and P/E ratio down. Intel in the meantime moves closer to 14nm production and total control over the fabrication space. What is so difficult for the morons on Wall Street to grasp? Oh that's right - they don't care about actual performance because they plan "to set" the Intel stock price. Something stinks here and it's the big firms on Wall Street setting defined stock price ranges. Not to mention the idea of Wall Street continuously attacking one of America's best companies. Enough is enough. It's time to take control back...

Message.Title: Williams Capital: Intel QCOM to benefit from Samsung announcement
Message.Msg: Williams Capital reports from the IFA Conference in Berlin The Williams analyst noted that Samsung announced it's launch of ATIV Windows 8 products (which included Windows 8 phone, tablet and notebooks). Samsung also introduced its own hybrid, called the Slate, a laptop with a detachable screen. Announcements of a new product line are expected next week by Nokia (NYSE: NOK) and HTC. Willams analyst expects these new product announcements to also benefit QUALCOMM (Nasdaq: QCOM), the company that will supply a dual-core 1.5 gigahertz chipset to the new Samsung smartphone. Also, Intel (Nasdaq: INTC) could see upside as its Core i3 and i5 product will be supplied in the new Samsung Laptop/Notebook.

Message.Title: Intel talks on Tuesday @Citi: Romit Shah reaffirms before talk
Message.Msg: Romit Shah has become a signal for anything happening relating to Intel. Nomura Securities Semiconductor Monitor: Q3 Booking Update After a round of Company meetings, analyst, Romit Shah, said, "We maintain a Neutral sector view. Top long ideas are Broadcom (Nasdaq: BRCM), Maxim (Nasdaq: MXIM), and Avago (Nasdaq: AVGO). Top short ideas are Intel (Nasdaq: INTC) and Marvell (Nasdaq: MRVL). China exports decelerated in July, PMI is at or below 50 across every region, and the major rail companies reported double-digit declines in volumes. Communcation infrastructure is better in N. America and China as carriers prepare for a new 4G iPhone (Nasdaq: AAPL). We also believe that our Q4 estimate of flat sequential growth on Broadcom could be conservative. Recent weakness in Maxim represents an attractive entry point, in our view. At the same time, we are incrementally more cautious on TI (NYSE: TXN)(Neutral). We believe PC fundamentals are subdued owing to high channel inventory and weak orders from PC OEMs."

Message.Title: Gartner expects India PC shipment growth to continue in the third quart
Message.Msg: Big winner in increase was Lenovo. Big loser was Dell. Dell lost market share to Lenovo. Gartner expects PC shipment growth to continue in the third quarter of 2012 owing to the festive season and education buying, coupled with some more fulfilment of the Tamilnadu Government order. Mobile PCs, which grew 54 percent compared to the second quarter of 2011, helped drive overall market growth. White boxes (including parallel import), which accounted for 45 percent of the overall desktop market, declined 18 percent in the second quarter of 2012 in comparison to the second quarter of 2011.

Message.Title: Barrons sez
Message.Msg: Regarding some recent estimate cuts for Intel (INTC), and the concern that the company may issue a warning for this quarter’s results, which Citigroup’s Glen Yeung speculated about on Monday, R.W. Baird’s Tristan Gerra this morning cut his numbers for the quarter, but wrote “We believe Intel still has a chance to meet the low end of its 3Q revenue guidance.” “Intel likely had visibility into the July weakness given the timing of the guidance, while an expected 20% rebound in September month over month should mitigate the early-quarter weakness, as OEMs ramp Windows 8-based PCs ahead of an October launch,” concludes Gerra. Gerra has an Outperform rating on Intel shares and a $33 price target.

Message.Title: ZTE rolls out 1st Intel phone in China
Message.Msg: ZTE Debuts Intel-based Grand X IN Smartphone By Mikael Ricknäs, IDG News Aug 30, 2012 9:00 am ZTE has introduced its first smartphone based Intel's Atom processor, the Z2460-powered Grand X IN. At the Mobile World Congress in February, Intel and ZTE announced that the Chinese phone maker would develop smartphones based on Intel's Atom processor, the first of which would arrive during the second half of 2012. ZTE has made good on that promise as the Grand X IN will start shipping in September in Europe. The Android 4.0-based smartphone's 4.3-inch screen has a 960-by-540 pixel resolution. That is a step up from the previously announced Orange Santa Clara, which uses the same Intel processor, but has a 4.03-inch screen with a 1024-by-600 pixel resolution. However, Lenovo's K800 has a bigger screen at 4.5 inches. The hardware specs also include an 8-megapixel camera, NFC, support for HD Voice and an FM radio. Users can access the Internet using HSDPA or Wi-Fi, including the 802.11n standard. ZTE didn't announce pricing for the Grand X IN. Intel's list of smartphone partners includes Lava, Orange, Lenovo, ZTE and Motorola Mobility. With Thursday's announcement all of them except for Motorola have announced a product. But Motorola is expected to join the others and debut its first Intel-based smartphone on Sept. 18 at an event in London.

Message.Title: Demand Creates Jobs
Message.Msg: In watching the Republican Convention, it appears that all of our country’s problems can be solved by cutting taxes and reducing regulations on small businesses. It’s time for a realty check. During the Bush administration both taxes and regulations were cut and look what happened; our country experienced slow growth, falling real wages, slow employment growth, a very substantial increase in our national debt, and the “Greatest Recession” in many of our lifetime. These facts can not be disputed. While I believe that the tax code should be completely revised and that some regulations need to be reviewed and perhaps eliminated, the Republican Party apparently does not understand that it is demand that creates growth, and consequently jobs; not lower taxes. If products are in demand and individuals have the funds available they will purchase them. Unfortunately over the past decade real wages have gone down as our country has transitioned from an industrial economy to a service economy. Adding to the problem has been the outsourcing of jobs overseas and the housing crash all of which have resulted in less cash in the pocketbook of the consumer. As a result, overall demand is down and consequently employment. What our country has to do is to get more money into the hands of the consumer. This can be done either through tax policy, public work projects, or an increase in the minimum wage. Reducing uncertainty and developing long-term solutions to the problems facing our country would also give our economy a psychological boost.

Topic.Title: Demand Creates Jobs

Message.Msg: I assume you believe we have done the opposite over the last 4 years. Well is their doubt the results are worse. This is on top of the fact that we have gone into even more debt to accomplish this feeble growth. Your demand argument is off base when you look at the economy globally. Borrowing money from China or the Middle East to buy oil and other products from them doesn't help our economy and only puts us more in debt. The best way to creat US jobs is to make our business more competitive by lowering taxes and regulations. We would then have more demad for our products both here and abroad. For example, letting us drill for more oil and gas would be miraculous for our economy.

Topic.Title: Tonshiba unveils 1st Ultrabook/Tablet Hybrid (Intel Inside)

Message.Msg: Hybrid laptop/tablet from MS, HP, Toshiba, and others ? These people are a disaster. Here's the correct product mix: Atom tablet for consumer. 10.1" screen. Optional (but expensive) home docking station. WiFi only but consider an ethernet plug instead of a docking station. Weight about 1 pound. Ivy Bridge tablet for business. 10.1" screen. Optional (but expensive) docking station. WiFi only but consider an ethernet plug instead of a docking station. Weight about 1 pound. Then a full line of thin and lightweight laptops and also known as the Ultrabook. Screen size starts at 11.6" and weight starts at two pounds. Screen size goes up to larger sizes and weight goes up to 3.5 pounds .

Message.Title: What's ailing Intel
Message.Msg: There has been a lot of chatter about the death of the PC, growth of mobile/tablets, and how and why Intel is not sucessful in penetrating the high growth market. I have nothing to add to those points. The simple reality is that PC growth is slowing due to the global economy, saturation, and competition for the wallet with mobile/tablets. What is curious are two points: 1. there is a myth that Intel just have to produce a good mobile/tablet to compete with ARM and the it will start to win the tablet market. I don't think so. The problem with Intel in mobile/tablet is not technoogy, is not the chip, it is not tri-gate transistors.....it is Intel's business model. ARM is a ubiquitous architecture that many know how to implement with many IPs available to work with the ARM core and many foundries who can build it. Intel's architecture is closed and only Intel can build it. It ain't going to work in mobile/tablets!! Intel made a feeble attempt to license Atom to TSMC but it went bust in less than one year. I know some of the folks involved and Intel's licensing fees and restrictions are so unrealistic nobody would bite. On top of that, there were no IPs to go with the core! The point is....22nm is not the answer. A new chip is not the answer. Intel needs a new business model. 2. Intel touts that mobile/tablet growth is still good for Intel because it means more data centers, more servers, etc.. It is true, for now, and to a certain extent. But let's not forget that Intel's huge (and hugely expensive) technoogy and manufacturing base requires a very large volume of chips to sustain. Server chips alone will never pay for the technology and manufacturing. And without technology and manufacturing, Intel's competitiveness is in question. Just look at IBM, Sun Microsystem, TI, Motorola, Fujitsu, Hitachi, Siemens, NCR....if you try to build a businessa round server chips alone, you can't afford the economics! All of the said, Intel still has a lot going for it. What Intel needs is new leadership and new management. A visionary who can take Intel outside of its traditions and grow in new, high grwoth areas. Otellini has been CEO now for almost 8 years. Sadly, none of the strategies he embarked on resulted in anything. It is time for a change!

Topic.Title: What's ailing Intel

Message.Msg: its a blue chip. it may be at 30 in a few years. but it aint goin nowhere soon.

Topic.Title: Demand Creates Jobs

Message.Msg: Just to make this a little on-topic, Intel has been a leader in keeping their production in the US and not outsourcing. That doesn't mean they don't hire a lot of H-1B, but it's something. Globalization is the big problem, but there are no easy or obvious solutions. And - try to talk anything complex these days, and nobody listens. I guess things just go as they will.

Message.Title: Motorola and Intel send invites to Sept. 18 event in London
Message.Msg: Aug 29th. Motorola and Intel sent invitations today for a Sept. 18 event in London. We have been waiting for the two companies to announce something since their partnership was revealed back at CES at the start of this year, and it looks like we will finally see the fruits of their efforts. Motorola and Intel did say that they would announce a Medfield-powered phone this year, so we are fairly certain that this is exactly what we will see at this event.Little is known about the first Intel-powered Motorola handset, but rumors speculate it will boast Android 4.0 to start and a stellar camera.

Topic.Title: Motorola and Intel send invites to Sept. 18 event in London

Message.Msg: Motorola Mobility, a subsidiary of Google, will reveal its very first smartphone based on Intel Atom Z2460 system-on-chip and Google Android 4 operating system next month in London, UK. The cellphone will be the first x86-based smartphone that will likely to be sold in the U.S. eventually.

There's only a couple of possibilities as to why he is here daily embarrassing himself: 1.) He's getting paid. 2.) Intel fired him or ran over his dog or put his start-up out of business. 3.) And those who take him seriously aren't either...

Message.Title: Fox News Shoots, They Score
Message.Msg: According to Fox News columnist Sally Kohn, vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan's speech at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday "was an apparent attempt to set the world record for the greatest number of blatant lies and misrepresentations slipped into a single political speech." "On this measure, while it was Romney who ran the Olympics, Ryan earned the gold," Kohn wrote. In a surprising move, Fox News joined CNN, The Huffington Post, the Washington Post's Wonkblog, and ThinkProgress in publishing a fact-check of the Republican vice presidential nominee's speech, finding that the speech was full of lies and misleading assertions.
